blog.title: I'm Just the Mechanic
blog.description: It's a big multiverse.  Anything can happen.Tony Stark: by day, an engineer working for Potts Enterprises, Manhattan; by night, and as needed, mechanic and gadgeteer for the mysterious superhero RescueI also sometimes rp on this blog as MCU Tony - all...

caption:
Our Own Demons

Part 1/? - A Bolt from the Blue
Part 2/? - A Different World
Part 3/? - Stark At Home
Part 4/? - Pot Roast Night
Part 5/? - Space-Pie Continuum
Part 6/? - Energy Signature
Part 7/? - Miss Potts
Part 8/? - Bot from Beyond
Part 9/? - Even the Odds
Part 10/? - Miss Potts Arrives

What if Tony Stark really were the villain of the Marvel universe?  How would that work?  Tony himself is about to find out, as he battles his inner demons (and some outer ones, too) across a multiverse of infinite possibilities.

The impact left Tony dazed, but the robot wasn’t subject to such things.  Before he had time to recover, it lifted Tony up and slammed him back down again.  He saw stars.  The only thing he could think of to do was to fire all the repulsors at once, driving himself and the robot into the pavement of 42nd Street.  They dug a furrow in the asphalt as they skidded along, throwing cars out of the way as they went.

The Proof of Concept really wasn’t built to take this kind of punishment, JANIS observed.

“If you can’t say anything useful you can shut the hell up!” Tony shouted.  He and the robot roared past the library and rammed into the steps to the 5th Avenue subway station, where they got stuck.  The robot grabbed Tony by the shoulder and lifted him to bang him against the stairs.

He was bracing for the impact when somebody caught him.  The red giantess ripped him out of the robot’s claws and then gave the machine a good hard kick.  The railings broke, and the robot went bouncing down the steps into the subway station.  Satisfied, the giantess put Tony down gently, and then ran after it.

Tony got up, took a deep breath and tried to stop his ears ringing, then ran after her.  “Hey!” he shouted.  What was it JANIS had called her?  “Dr. Ross!  Dr. Ross!  Try and get a hand between those armor plates!”

There weren’t a lot of people taking the number seven train at one in the morning, but half a dozen or so were still screaming and running for the other exit as the giantess and the robot grappled on the platform.  She’d wrapped her legs around it and was pulling at something, while it slammed her repeatedly into an ad for The Lion King on Broadway.  Finally she lost her grip and dropped to the floor, apparently unconscious.  The robot rearranged itself and picked up a heavy wooden bench, ready to crush her with it.

But when it moved, Tony saw that one of the plates was bent open, exposing a layer of carbon fiber weave inside.  Good.

Tony ran up and blasted the bench out of its arms with a repulsor.  It went flying and landed across the track.  “Here I am!  Come and get me!” Tony ordered.  He jumped down to the track, and kicked the bench aside.

The robot had taken quite a bit of damage on the trip down 42nd.  Some of its joints were sparking and one leg was dragging, but it crawled towards him gamely enough, rotating the damaged portion away from him.  As it scuttled down onto the tracks, Tony fired his thrusters just hard enough to somersault over it and grab the exposed fibers with both hands.  Upon landing, he brought his boots down on the third rail.

Carbon fiber didn’t burn, but it did conduct electricity.

Nearly seven hundred volts crackled over the skin of the suit, and passed across the gauntlets into the robot’s interior.  The mesh built in kept the current from reaching Tony’s body, but the HUD turned to static and the servos seized, locking Tony in one place.  A moment later the display flickered back to life, but the lights were out in the subway station.

“JANIS, switch to night vision,” he ordered.

We don’t have that, the computer said.  Would you like the flashlight?

“Yes,” said Tony.

Yes, what?

“Yes, please,” he groaned.

A light came on in the suit’s chest, and fell on the remains of the robot, smoking and twitching on the tracks in front of Tony.  He gave it a kick to be sure it wasn’t faking, but it did not respond.  Apparently they’d beaten it.

Satisfied of that, Tony climbed back onto the platform to look for the giantess.  There was no sign of her at first, which left him wondering how an eight-foot red woman just disappeared.  Then, however, he saw the shape lying half-conscious below the Lion King ad.  She was of perfectly normal stature and had fair Caucasian skin, but she was wearing the black sports bra and bike shorts, both stretched out a bit too big for her.

Tony held out a gauntleted hand to her.  “Dr. Ross?” he asked.

She took his hand and was coughing as he helped her up..  “If I’d known I was coming back to this,” she said, “I would have stayed in Canada.”

“Are you hurt?” Tony wanted to know.

“Of course not,” she scoffed, and although she looked rather haggard and exhausted, she didn’t seem to be bleeding.  She was certainly able to stand.

“All right,” he said.  “Let’s get back to the building.”

There were now a dozen police cars, as well as fire trucks and ambulances, surrounding the entrance to Grand Central Station.  Tony’s counterpart was not in evidence, but there was a woman hurrying down the steps.  Tony recognized her at once.  How could he not?

This was it, then.  He was about to meet this world’s Pepper Potts.

She wore her hair short, which made sense.  Long hair would easily get tangled in the inner workings of the suit.  And she was dressed in jogging clothes – a pair of yoga pants and one of those wicking shirts.  When she saw Tony and Dr. Ross, she stopped short on the bottom step.  Her eyes flicked from one to the other, as if she couldn’t decide which of them she was more astonished to see.

“Betty!  Are you all right?” she asked, running to meet them.

“I’ll live,” Dr. Ross replied.  Tony handed her off to Miss Potts, who helped the other woman sit down on the steps and wrapped her own jacket around her.  The EMTs started to approach, but Dr. Ross shook her head, and Miss Potts waved them away.  She sat with her a while longer, and then got up to confront Tony.

“Tony,” she said, coming up to look him in the eye.  “What in the world is going on?”

Yeah, that was Pepper Potts, all right.  Tony held his hands up.  “I’m not Tony,” he said.

Miss Potts paused and looked him over, taking in the beard and the fact that he was wearing the suit, and nodded slowly.  “Then who are you?” she asked.

“That’s his cousin!” another voice panted, and Beth the security guard arrived.  She was now wearing a leather jacket over a knee-length black dress covered in sequins – she must have been out somewhere, only for the robot fight to get her attention when she realized it was at her workplace.  She was out of breath and running awkwardly in her high heeled shoes.  “That’s his cousin Arno.  From Italy,” she said, as she stopped to catch her breath.

Miss Potts bit her lip and looked Tony over.  “Bullshit,” she declared.

“Every word,” Tony agreed with a nervous chuckle.  “Look, we’ll explain, but I gotta make sure he’s okay first.”

“Make sure who’s okay?” Miss Potts asked.

“Tony,” said Tony, feeling stupid saying it.

Several expressions crossed her face, including cynicism, an urge to laugh, and anger, and then she settled on curiosity.  “I’m coming with you,” she said.  “Ms. Cabe, can you look after Betty, please?”

“I don’t need looking after,” Dr. Ross complained.

“Of course, Miss Potts,” said Beth, and sat down beside Dr. Ross.

Tony had left his double by the ticket counters.  With the suit on it was very awkward to climb over and through the rubble to get back to him, but Tony felt unwilling to take it off.  That robot had come out of nowhere, and who knew what might prompt a second one to materialize.

“You’re the one who phoned me the other day,” Miss Potts said, picking her way through the wreckage behind him with far more grace.  “Are you the one who shut down the suits?”

“Yes, but it’s kind of a long story,” said Tony.  He heaved himself up on the counter, and looked down.  There was his double, curled up and grimacing in pain.  “Found him!”

“Tony!”  Miss Potts climbed over the counter and dropped down next to him.

“I’m fine, I’m fine,” said the other, holding up a hand.

“No, you’re not,” said Miss Potts.  “But you will be.  Arno, go get the EMTs.”

It took Tony a moment to realize that by ‘Arno’ she meant him.  He hadn’t given her another name to call him.  “On my way.”

Circumstances being what they were, he waited until he was out of the suit and the two of them were sitting in a hospital waiting room while his counterpart’s ribs got x-rayed before he said, “my name isn’t Arno, by the way.”

“I didn’t think it was,” Miss Potts replied, nervously fiddling with her phone.  She was scrolling through news websites too fast to actually read them… she must be looking at the pictures and taking in the sound bites instead.  There were images of the destruction around Grand Central, a blurry cell phone photo of Dr. Ross and the robot up on the Chrysler Building, and a clearer but still amateur photograph of Tony in the armor, picking himself up off the street.  The tag said who is the iron man?  Some things didn’t change.

Some things did, though.  This woman looked so exactly like Pepper… but apparently in this world it was her doing the superheroing.  Tony’s gut wanted to tell her that she didn’t have – that whatever reason made her feel like she had to carry the fate of the world herself, it couldn’t be as bad as some of the stuff he’d done, never mind the stuff he should have done and hadn’t.  He didn’t, though, because she might have asked what he’d done and failed to do… and that was no way to make an impression on some other universe’s Miss Potts.

Instead, therefore, they just sat there awkwardly, not looking at each other.  Miss Potts concentrated on her phone, and Tony kept glancing up at the television in the corner, which was playing a curling match.  Tony knew nothing about curling besides a vague impression that it was cold bowling in slow motion.  Who would have ever thought he’d find himself next to Pepper Potts with nothing to say to her?

“I guess you probably want to know the whole story,” he offered.  That would certainly pass the time.

“I do,” she agreed quietly, “but I think I want to hear it from Tony.”

Tony took two things from that – one was that she didn’t trust him.  Maybe, like his double, she assumed the beard made him the evil one.  Or maybe she was just generally suspicious of this man who looked exactly like her favourite employee except for being able to fly her suits.  Maybe she was mad because people didn’t know she was Iron Woman or whatever, and him appearing in the suit might have compromised that.  He could think of all sorts of reasons, really.  Tony was just not a trustworthy person.

The other thing was that she did trust her Tony, and was very worried about his welfare.  That was a possible opening.

“He cares a lot about you, you know,” he said.

“Hm?” Miss Potts asked, looking up from her phone.

“Him.  Tony,” he said.  It still felt weird saying his own name and meaning somebody else, even when he had met other Tonys in the past.  This was different.  “He cares a lot about you,” he repeated.

“I know,” said Miss Potts, turning her phone over and looking at the ceiling.

“No, I mean, he really…” Tony paused, rubbing the back of his neck.  How did you tell somebody that your alternate universe self was in love with her?  There was no script for that.  “He’s had a thing for you since you hired him, but he’s worried you’ll think he’s trespassing your boundaries…”

It was both a frustration and a relief that a woman in scrubs chose that moment to approach them.  “Ms. Potts?” she asked.

“Yes, I’m Virginia Potts.”  Miss Potts stood, pulling her purse strap up her shoulder.

“Your employee has two broken ribs but he won’t require surgery.  We’ve taped him up and given him some morphine, and we’re discharging him now.”

“Thank you,” said Miss Potts, with a smile that was equal parts polite and relieved.  “I’ll take him home now.”  Then she paused as she realized something important.  “I don’t actually know where Tony lives.”

“No problem,” said Tony himself, happy to be able to contribute something.  “I do.”

“Tony,” she said, coming up to look him in the eye.  “What in the world is going on?”

Yeah, that was Pepper Potts, all right.  Tony held his hands up.  “I’m not Tony,” he said.

Miss Potts paused and looked him over, taking in the beard and the fact that he was wearing the suit, and nodded slowly.  “Then who are you?” she asked.

“That’s his cousin!” another voice panted, and Beth the security guard arrived.  She was now wearing a leather jacket over a knee-length black dress covered in sequins – she must have been out somewhere, only for the robot fight to get her attention when she realized it was at her workplace.  She was out of breath and running awkwardly in her high heeled shoes.  “That’s his cousin Arno.  From Italy,” she said, as she stopped to catch her breath.

Miss Potts bit her lip and looked Tony over.  “Bullshit,” she declared.

“Every word,” Tony agreed with a nervous chuckle.  “Look, we’ll explain, but I gotta make sure he’s okay first.”

“Make sure who’s okay?” Miss Potts asked.

“Tony,” said Tony, feeling stupid saying it.

Several expressions crossed her face, including cynicism, an urge to laugh, and anger, and then she settled on curiosity.  “I’m coming with you,” she said.  “Ms. Cabe, can you look after Betty, please?”

“I don’t need looking after,” Dr. Ross complained.

“Of course, Miss Potts,” said Beth, and sat down beside Dr. Ross.

Tony had left his double by the ticket counters.  With the suit on it was very awkward to climb over and through the rubble to get back to him, but Tony felt unwilling to take it off.  That robot had come out of nowhere, and who knew what might prompt a second one to materialize.

“You’re the one who phoned me the other day,” Miss Potts said, picking her way through the wreckage behind him with far more grace.  “Are you the one who shut down the suits?”

“Yes, but it’s kind of a long story,” said Tony.  He heaved himself up on the counter, and looked down.  There was his double, curled up and grimacing in pain.  “Found him!”

“Tony!”  Miss Potts climbed over the counter and dropped down next to him.

“I’m fine, I’m fine,” said the other, holding up a hand.

“No, you’re not,” said Miss Potts.  “But you will be.  Arno, go get the EMTs.”

It took Tony a moment to realize that by ‘Arno’ she meant him.  He hadn’t given her another name to call him.  “On my way.”

Circumstances being what they were, he waited until he was out of the suit and the two of them were sitting in a hospital waiting room while his counterpart’s ribs got x-rayed before he said, “my name isn’t Arno, by the way.”

“I didn’t think it was,” Miss Potts replied, nervously fiddling with her phone.  She was scrolling through news websites too fast to actually read them… she must be looking at the pictures and taking in the sound bites instead.  There were images of the destruction around Grand Central, a blurry cell phone photo of Dr. Ross and the robot up on the Chrysler Building, and a clearer but still amateur photograph of Tony in the armor, picking himself up off the street.  The tag said who is the iron man?  Some things didn’t change.

Some things did, though.  This woman looked so exactly like Pepper… but apparently in this world it was her doing the superheroing.  Tony’s gut wanted to tell her that she didn’t have – that whatever reason made her feel like she had to carry the fate of the world herself, it couldn’t be as bad as some of the stuff he’d done, never mind the stuff he should have done and hadn’t.  He didn’t, though, because she might have asked what he’d done and failed to do… and that was no way to make an impression on some other universe’s Miss Potts.

Instead, therefore, they just sat there awkwardly, not looking at each other.  Miss Potts concentrated on her phone, and Tony kept glancing up at the television in the corner, which was playing a curling match.  Tony knew nothing about curling besides a vague impression that it was cold bowling in slow motion.  Who would have ever thought he’d find himself next to Pepper Potts with nothing to say to her?

“I guess you probably want to know the whole story,” he offered.  That would certainly pass the time.

“I do,” she agreed quietly, “but I think I want to hear it from Tony.”

Tony took two things from that – one was that she didn’t trust him.  Maybe, like his double, she assumed the beard made him the evil one.  Or maybe she was just generally suspicious of this man who looked exactly like her favourite employee except for being able to fly her suits.  Maybe she was mad because people didn’t know she was Iron Woman or whatever, and him appearing in the suit might have compromised that.  He could think of all sorts of reasons, really.  Tony was just not a trustworthy person.

The other thing was that she did trust her Tony, and was very worried about his welfare.  That was a possible opening.

“He cares a lot about you, you know,” he said.

“Hm?” Miss Potts asked, looking up from her phone.

“Him.  Tony,” he said.  It still felt weird saying his own name and meaning somebody else, even when he had met other Tonys in the past.  This was different.  “He cares a lot about you,” he repeated.

“I know,” said Miss Potts, turning her phone over and looking at the ceiling.

“No, I mean, he really…” Tony paused, rubbing the back of his neck.  How did you tell somebody that your alternate universe self was in love with her?  There was no script for that.  “He’s had a thing for you since you hired him, but he’s worried you’ll think he’s trespassing your boundaries…”

It was both a frustration and a relief that a woman in scrubs chose that moment to approach them.  “Ms. Potts?” she asked.

“Yes, I’m Virginia Potts.”  Miss Potts stood, pulling her purse strap up her shoulder.

“Your employee has two broken ribs but he won’t require surgery.  We’ve taped him up and given him some morphine, and we’re discharging him now.”

“Thank you,” said Miss Potts, with a smile that was equal parts polite and relieved.  “I’ll take him home now.”  Then she paused as she realized something important.  “I don’t actually know where Tony lives.”

“No problem,” said Tony himself, happy to be able to contribute something.  “I do.”

The impact left Tony dazed, but the robot wasn’t subject to such things.  Before he had time to recover, it lifted Tony up and slammed him back down again.  He saw stars.  The only thing he could think of to do was to fire all the repulsors at once, driving himself and the robot into the pavement of 42nd Street.  They dug a furrow in the asphalt as they skidded along, throwing cars out of the way as they went.

The Proof of Concept really wasn’t built to take this kind of punishment, JANIS observed.

“If you can’t say anything useful you can shut the hell up!” Tony shouted.  He and the robot roared past the library and rammed into the steps to the 5th Avenue subway station, where they got stuck.  The robot grabbed Tony by the shoulder and lifted him to bang him against the stairs.

He was bracing for the impact when somebody caught him.  The red giantess ripped him out of the robot’s claws and then gave the machine a good hard kick.  The railings broke, and the robot went bouncing down the steps into the subway station.  Satisfied, the giantess put Tony down gently, and then ran after it.

Tony got up, took a deep breath and tried to stop his ears ringing, then ran after her.  “Hey!” he shouted.  What was it JANIS had called her?  “Dr. Ross!  Dr. Ross!  Try and get a hand between those armor plates!”

Tony ran up and blasted the bench out of its arms with a repulsor.  It went flying and landed across the track.  “Here I am!  Come and get me!” Tony ordered.  He jumped down to the track, and kicked the bench aside.

Carbon fiber didn’t burn, but it did conduct electricity.

Nearly seven hundred volts crackled over the skin of the suit, and passed across the gauntlets into the robot’s interior.  The mesh built in kept the current from reaching Tony’s body, but the HUD turned to static and the servos seized, locking Tony in one place.  A moment later the display flickered back to life, but the lights were out in the subway station.

“JANIS, switch to night vision,” he ordered.

We don’t have that, the computer said.  Would you like the flashlight?

“Yes,” said Tony.

Yes, what?

“Yes, please,” he groaned.

A light came on in the suit’s chest, and fell on the remains of the robot, smoking and twitching on the tracks in front of Tony.  He gave it a kick to be sure it wasn’t faking, but it did not respond.  Apparently they’d beaten it.

Satisfied of that, Tony climbed back onto the platform to look for the giantess.  There was no sign of her at first, which left him wondering how an eight-foot red woman just disappeared.  Then, however, he saw the shape lying half-conscious below the Lion King ad.  She was of perfectly normal stature and had fair Caucasian skin, but she was wearing the black sports bra and bike shorts, both stretched out a bit too big for her.

Tony held out a gauntleted hand to her.  “Dr. Ross?” he asked.

She took his hand and was coughing as he helped her up..  “If I’d known I was coming back to this,” she said, “I would have stayed in Canada.”

“Are you hurt?” Tony wanted to know.

“Of course not,” she scoffed, and although she looked rather haggard and exhausted, she didn’t seem to be bleeding.  She was certainly able to stand.

“All right,” he said.  “Let’s get back to the building.”

There were now a dozen police cars, as well as fire trucks and ambulances, surrounding the entrance to Grand Central Station.  Tony’s counterpart was not in evidence, but there was a woman hurrying down the steps.  Tony recognized her at once.  How could he not?

This was it, then.  He was about to meet this world’s Pepper Potts.

She wore her hair short, which made sense.  Long hair would easily get tangled in the inner workings of the suit.  And she was dressed in jogging clothes – a pair of yoga pants and one of those wicking shirts.  When she saw Tony and Dr. Ross, she stopped short on the bottom step.  Her eyes flicked from one to the other, as if she couldn’t decide which of them she was more astonished to see.

summary: People who hate Tony confuse me to no end. Like sure, he doesn't have to be your favorite. You don't have to like him. I get...
body:
People who hate Tony confuse me to no end. Like sure, he doesn’t have to be your favorite. You don’t have to like him. I get that his personality can be annoying to some people, too.

But, people who hate him, explain your thinking, please, because I can’t understand how you can hate someone so much like that. And you know what’s funny?? You’re wasting time hating a morally good fictional character instead of a real person who’s racist or sexist or whatever. Why do you invest time in hating a made up person?

And if it’s because it’s RDJ, then just don’t watch the movies or be in the Marvel Fandom at all, because RDJ is the only way these movies happened. Had he failed at Ironman 1, none of the movies you love would’ve happened, at least not with the same cast and same ideas. So if you dislike Tony because of RDJ, you might as well leave, and if you hate Tony, you need to find a better hobby, babe.

summary: “I’ll call him... Venny.”
body:
“I’ll call him… Venny.”

Merry Ambiguous Midwinter Holiday, @megnetsworld

This is your gift!

The quiet tapping of flesh against datapad was the dominant sound in the lab. Tony Stark and Bruce Banner were hard at work with their newest project – some space goop found just off the coast. Bruce had his eyed glued to a microscope as Tony flicked through pages of research.

They had been at this for hours already, barely looking away even when Peter swung by on his way to school.

“Huh. A lot of our tests have returned positive for those serotonin inhibitors we found.” The billionaire yawned quietly, eyes blinking at the screen full of experiment data.

“Yeah.” Bruce did not look away, “Everything points more and more toward heightening aggression in any life forms the symbiote bonds with.” He fingered a dial on the microscope, adjusting his view of a piece of the odd organism.

“Where’d you put the rest of it again?”

“The tube’s in the bag over there.”

Tony barely paused, “Just a paper bag? Really?”

“I needed something quick to keep it in the dark. Light seems to overstimulate it sometimes.”

Tony approached the paper bag, eyeing the smiley face with a bemused gaze.

“Light, huh? Well, let’s take a look.” With deft fingers, Tony uncurled the mouth of the bag and pulled out its contents.

Bruce rubbed some soreness out of his neck, refusing to take his eyes off his subject.

“Uh, Banner?”

“Yeah?”

“Can this stuff –” Tony hesitated, his question sounding dumb before it left his lips. Perhaps they had been at this longer than he thought, “—it can’t transform into food, can it?”

“Uh… no?”

“Then, uh, what am I looking at?”

Bruce finally tore his gaze away from the fascinating phenomenon, turning to where Tony was holding a peanut butter sandwich in his shaking fingers.

“Looks like lunch.”

“This is Peter’s lunch!” The man dropped the sandwich back into the bag, not allowing his frantic stare to leave Bruce’s.

They stared at each other, neither blinking despite the tired eyes they shared.

“Uh oh.”

…

In mere minutes, Banner had a headset on, and was flicking through file after file reading off information about the symbiote.

Tony was listening as he shot threw the air towards Peter’s school.

“Subject has shown to heighten aggressive tendencies when in contact with other organisms. It bonds with its host, feeding off that aggression and invading its host’s psyche. Oh man, Tony. If we don’t do something quick, Peter could lose himself. He might not be Peter anymore.”

Tony chose not to respond, instead merely scowling as his intuitive armor picked up on his growing distress and accelerated accordingly.

“Oh, god.” Bruce gasped as he landed on yet another page of notes and discoveries, “When tested with the lambs, the host tried to eat three other lambs. Tony, what if Peter—”

“Don’t you dare finish that sentence.”

Bruce gulped and nodded.

Iron Man descended with fervor, nearly crashing into two different cars as he landed. His nanotech suit dissolved around him, leaving him in the tee shirt and jeans he had been wearing in the lab.

Tony Stark walked right through the front doors and barely acknowledged the front office. He knew Peter’s schedule by now. He knew that Peter had lunch from 12:30 to 1:30. As calmly as he could, Tony strode into the cafeteria and power-walked toward the three nerds that sat in the farthest table over.

He approached Peter from behind, and the boy’s friend – Ned? – glanced up in awe.

“Whoa! Hi Mr. Stark! We were just talking about you”

Tony nodded shortly as Peter spun around with the biggest grin on his face. A sentient black blob hanging from his neck, seemingly docile.

“Mr. Stark! Can I keep him?”

Tony blinked, letting F.R.I.D.A.Y. analyze his vitals and nervous system as he tried to comprehend the situation.

“K-keep him? No! He could be dangerous!”

“Aw, this little guy? No way.”

“Yes, ‘way,’” Tony nearly growled, “We have no idea what that thing is or does.”

“He cuddles is what he does.”

“Peter—”

“Tony—”

Tony froze, then sighed, speaking into his headset but not taking his eyes off of the boy before him, “Whatcha got, Bruce?”

“Peter’s fine. He’s showing no signs of lowered serotonin, his heartrate is even, everything seems to be in order.”

“What about the symbiote’s effects?” Tony ignored the ‘symbiote?’ and ‘cool!’ that came from Peter and Ned, “What about the aggression?”

“Negative, and negative. If anything, the symbiote is actually taking on Peter’s qualities instead of the other way around.”

“… Wait.” Tony stared into Peter’s hopeful gaze.

“Yeah?”

“You’re telling me—” Peter’s grin widened when the black sludge slid up onto his shoulder, staying perched there with minimal contact with his neck. “—That Peter is literally so pure, that he corrupted the alien parasite?”

Bruce’s voice came through with equal trepidation, “… I think so, yeah.”

“So, can I keep him? Please?”

title: How to live a double life without being outed in the process
body:
read it on the AO3 at http://bit.ly/2EMqotb

by CrispBagel

How does Peter keep his Spider-Man identity a secret while living among the Avengers? With difficulty.

First there’s Shuri and Loki.

And oh god, Tony and Clint

Thor… he’s not sure

Steve, Bruce and Natasha, along with the others are fine… Right?

———————————————————-

This is my first Fic. Ever. So criticism is greatly appreciated! More details about the AU in the notes.

summary: Not Black and White
title: Not Black and White
body:
read it on the AO3 at http://bit.ly/2EQplt6

by Reiko009

AKA “Sex Ed with the Avengers”

Life on Earth after Thanos is peaceful - at least for now. Which means the team has an opportunity to heal old wounds, talk, and learn more about themselves. An incident with some overzealous fans brings up the need to bring in an expert. Secrets are revealed and budding relationships soon blossom. But things aren’t always easy - the road to happiness takes some unexpected detours before their journey’s end.

Free-form and dialogue heavy. No spoilers in the tags for a reason!

Words: 4741, Chapters: 1/1, Language: English

  • Fandoms: The Avengers (Marvel Movies), The Avengers (Marvel) - All Media Types
  • Rating: Mature
  • Warnings: Creator Chose Not To Use Archive Warnings
  • Categories: M/M
  • Characters: Tony Stark, Steve Rogers, James “Bucky” Barnes, Hulk (Marvel), Bruce Banner, Stephen Strange, Thor (Marvel), Pepper Potts, Natasha Romanov (Marvel), Original Characters
  • Additional Tags: Sex Education, Homosexuality, Bisexuality, Demisexuality, Asexuality, Coming Out, Counselling, Period-Typical Homophobia, Developing Relationship, past trauma, Post-Avengers: Infinity War Part 1 (Movie), talking about sex

by ohutblog

Thor Borson is known for his arrogance, his ill-considered actions and his cockiness. A bad mix, which led to a terrible accident two years ago, of which only few know. Thor was hardly injured. After his punishment, Thor must find his way back to his life and will learn that his recklessness not only has dire consequences for himself but also negatively affects others.
